IntroductionÂ¶

As say before, MathML is a specification for describing mathemathics. The equation below are write using MathML

x = - b ± b 2 - 4 ⁢ a ⁢ c 2 ⁢ a

and produce by the following code:

<math>
<mrow>
 <mi>x</mi>
 <mo>=</mo>
 <mfrac>
   <mrow>
     <mrow>
       <mo>-</mo>
       <mi>b</mi>
     </mrow>
     <mo>&#xB1;<!--PLUS-MINUS SIGN--></mo>
     <msqrt>
       <mrow>
         <msup>
           <mi>b</mi>
           <mn>2</mn>
         </msup>
         <mo>-</mo>
         <mrow>
           <mn>4</mn>
           <mo>&#x2062;<!--INVISIBLE TIMES--></mo>
           <mi>a</mi>
           <mo>&#x2062;<!--INVISIBLE TIMES--></mo>
           <mi>c</mi>
         </mrow>
       </mrow>
     </msqrt>
   </mrow>
   <mrow>
     <mn>2</mn>
     <mo>&#x2062;<!--INVISIBLE TIMES--></mo>
     <mi>a</mi>
   </mrow>
 </mfrac>
</mrow>
</math>

The last version is MathML 3.0 that was release as W3C Recommendation on 21 October 2010.

MathML is an application of XML, Extensible Markup Language, and as such it is governed by the rules of XML syntax. XML syntax is a notation for rooted labeled planar trees. Planarity means that the children of a node may be viewed as given a natural order and MathML depends on this order.

MathML presentation elements only recommend (i.e., do not require) specific ways of rendering; this is in order to allow for medium-dependent rendering and for individual preferences of style.

References

[1]http://www.w3.org/TR/MathML3/chapter2.html
